titleStmt.title: F-1ie7: New York, The Morgan Library, M. 564; Nuremberg, Germanisches Nationalmuseum, Hs. 27932; Nuremberg, Stadtbibliothek, Fragm. Lat. 1

editionStmt.edition: Digital edition according to TEI P5

availability.licence: This document is published under the Creative Commons licence Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0).

head.title: Quattuor Evangelia
head.note: This Uncial manuscript of the four Gospels was probably written in Mondsee in the second half of the eight century. The manuscript was at some point discarded and used as binding waste. Preserved are 58 folios (18 in New York and 36 in Nuremberg GNM and 8 in Nuremberg Stadtbibliothek). The leaves contain part of the Gospel of Luke and the Gospel of John. At least two sexternions are missing with the beginning of Luke (1,1-5,19) and another two or three quires at the end of John (12,40-21,25).

incipit.ref: cum lecto in medium ante ihesum

msItem.note: Lacuna (1 fol.) with the end of Luke (24,46-24,53) and beginning of the Prolog to John.

msItem.title: Prologus monarchianus in evangelium secundum Johannem
msItem.incipit: conuocatis discipulis suis in epheso per multa signorum experimenta

msItem.rubric: Incipit elencus breuis euangelii secundum iohannem

msItem.incipit: et quod ipse in patre et pater in illo est
msItem.explicit: XIIII Passio et sepultura et resurrectio eius.

msItem.note: Lacuna until the end of John (ca. 24 fols. = 2 sexternions).

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Carolingian minuscule for the Canon references in the margin.
Capitalis rustica used for the prologue and Summarium (f. 23r-v).

listBibl.bibl: Wright, David H. ‘The Codex Millenarius and Its Model’. Münchner Jahrbuch der bildenden Kunst 15 (1964): 37–54.
Holter, Kurt. ‘Das Alte und Neue Testament in Buchmalerei nördlich der Alpen’. In La bibblia nell’alto medioevo (Settimane di studio del Centro italiano di studi sull’alto medioevo, 10), 413–72.

supportDesc.extent:
18
317.5 190.5 (according to description of the Pierpont Morgan Library).

binding.p: Information from the Morgan cards catalogue: the fragments are kept in a wooden box assembled in Germany in the 19th-century. On the upper cover in the middle of a gilt-metal sheet (probably 13th-century) is an enamel plaque of Christ in majesty (probably 12th-century) in center and symbols of the Evangelists at the corners, surrounded by metal bands studded with crystals. The symbols of the Evangelists are copies of 13th- or 14th-century pieces.
The Catalogus of Sir Thomas Phillipps mentions that the fragments were already at the time (1837) bound in red velvet and that one cover was decorated with rock crystals set in silver gilt.

physDesc.accMat: By the acquisition the leaves were wrapped in a fragment (two leaves - probably bifolium) from a 11th-century Lectionary, according to the catalogue of the Morgan library - written in a Bavarian or Austrian hand.

history.provenance: The leaves served as binding waste (wrappers, covers ?) for property registers of the Nuremberg family of Von Kress.
The fragments were later (ca. 1680) owned by Baron J. W. Imhoff, later by his heir Baron Haller von Hallerstein.

The fragments were sold several times: 1861 in an auction in Nuremberg acquired by the dealer Tross, then by Guillaume Libri, who sold them to Sir Thomas Phillipps (in his Catalogus, p. 317, No. 16387), by Richard Bennett and lastly by Pierpont Morgan.

listBibl.bibl: Koehler, Wilhelm. ‘The Fragments of an Eighth-Century Gospel Book in the Morgan Library (M.564): A Contribution to the History of the Vulgate’. In Studies in Art and Literature for Belle Da Costa Greene. Ed. by Dorothy Miner. Princeton: Princeton Univ. Press, 1954, pp. 238–65.
Catalogus librorum manuscriptorum in bibliotheca D. Thomae Phillipps, Bart. Middle Hill, 1837, p. 317.

msItem.note: Here follows Nürnberg, Stadtbibliothek, Fragm. Lat. 1, 3v (1 column for the end of the Summarium, rest left blank).
Lacuna (2 fols.), followed by Morgan library, M 564, f. 9 (Io 2,14-3,3), Lacuna (10 fols.) and Morgan library, M 564, f. 10r-v (Io 6,16-6,30).
Lacuna (1 fol.) followed by Morgan library, M 564 ff. 11-16 (Io 7,6-8,42).
Lacuna (2 fols.) followed by Morgan library, M 564, f. 17 (Io 10,17-10,33) another lacuna (6 fols.) and Morgan library, M 564, f. 18 (Io 12,26-12,39).

supportDesc.support: Calf parchment relative thin, hair and flesh side are recognisable. Backbone on fol. 18-19 horizontal in the middle of the bifolium (as in Lindisfarne) - probably also on fols. 12-13 and 21-22, 20ter-20bis.
supportDesc.condition: There are three groups of leaves bound in modern paper folders. Hs 27932 [1.0] contains fols. 1-20, 20a-20d, 21, 21a-21b, 22-24; Hs 27932 [1-1] - fols. 20bis-20ter; Hs 27932 [1.2] - fols. 21a-21b; Hs 27932 [2] - fols. 25-28. Fols. 20a-20d are glued in pairs on a stub, whereby fols. 20a and 20d make today one bifolium, 20b and 20c another. Comparing the marks from binding waste (the leaves were used as covers) it becomes clear that fols. 20a and 20b formed originally once one bifolium, fols. 20c and 20d another.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruling probably direct on fol. 4v-5r, 12v-13r and 18v-19r (innermost leaves of quires) on flesh side; probably also direct ruling on 2v-7r on hair side -> it would mean the leaves were ruled in pairs of three. On fol. 10v-15r (third leaf) on hair side - probably indirect ruling. on fols. 17v-20r (fourth leaf) on flesh side - probably indirect ruling. 20ter r and 20 bis v - on hair side - probably indirect ruling. 21v-22r - on hair side - probably indirect ruling. 23v-24r - on hair side - probably indirect ruling. 20ter-20bis - on hair side. Double ruled lines for the text (upper line on the x-height); the first and last double text lines extending the lenght of the folio (probably ruled on two facing pages at once); double columns with double vertical bounding lines extending to first and last double written lines; single vertical lines on both sides of the columns extending to the first and last double written lines

decoDesc.decoNote:
Six illuminated initials, contour in red (Mennige); Colours: green, orange-red, gold and silver-blue. First probably with blue, then covered with gold and silver.
4r: 2-line high ornamental initial 'C'
10r: 2-line high ornamental initial 'C'
17r: 3-line high ornamental initial 'C'
20cv: 3-line high figural initial 'E'
21r: 4-line high ornamental initial 'A'
20ter: 4-line high ornamental initial 'A'

history.provenance:
In the first half of the seventeenth century the leaves 1-24 and 21a-21b served as binding waste (wrappers and covers) for property registers of the Nuremberg family Von Kress. For each register were used two bifolia:
fols. 1+8 and 9+16
fols. 2+7 and 10+15 - register 'Saalbuch A 1590';
fols. 3+6 and 11+14 - register for years 1594-1627
fols. 4+5 and 12+13
fols. 17+20 and 18+19 were used for register in the year 'Anno 1627-1650'
fols. 21a+21b and 20bis+20ter
fols. 21+22 and 23+24 - register 1637;
Fols. 1-24 were obtained 1872 by the Germanisches Museum in Nuremberg.
Fols. 20a-20d were property of the Heerdegen family in Nuremberg, who gave or sold those 1874 to the Germanisches Museum.

The two bifolia fols. 25-28 and 26-27 served as a pastedowns for 'Grundbuch für die Jahresbeiträge der Pflegschaft' of the Nuremberg family Von Grundherr. They were again given or sold to the Germanisches Museum.
The boflolium fols. 21a-21b was bought by the Germanisches Museum in 1923.

The leaves were used as binding waste (covers) for two register books from the 1615. For each cover were used two bifolia, glued at the spine of the book. Fols. 1+2 were glued on the front cover, fols. 8+9 on the back cover of one register; fols. 7+6 were glued on the front cover, fols. 3+4 on the back cover of the second part of the register.

projectDesc.p: Description originated within the project "The Carolingian Scriptorium of Mondsee".
